Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 16, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
You know that little pink thing nestled 
in the corner of your eye? It’s actually the remnant 
of a third eyelid. Known as the “plica semilunaris,” it’s much more prominent in birds 
and a few mammals, and functions like a windshield wiper 
to keep dust and debris out of their eyes. But in humans, it doesn’t work. It’s vestigial, meaning it no longer 
serves its original purpose. There are several other vestigial 
structures like the plica semilunaris in the human body. Most of these became vestigial long 
before homo sapiens existed, quietly riding along from one of 
our ancestor species to the next. But why have they stuck 
around for so long? To answer this question, it helps to 
understand natural selection. Natural selection simply means that traits which help an organism survive and 
reproduce in a given environment are more likely to make it to the 
next generation. As the environment changes, traits 
that were once useful can become harmful. Those traits are often selected against, meaning they gradually disappear 
from the population. But if a trait isn’t actively harmful, 
it might not get selected against, and stick around even 
though it isn’t useful. Take the tailbone. Evolutionary biologists think that as the 
climate got drier and grasslands popped up, our tail-bearing ancestors left the trees 
and started walking on land. The tails that had helped them 
in the trees began to disrupt their ability 
to walk on land. So individuals with mutations that reduced
the length of their tails became more successful at life on land, surviving long enough to pass their short 
tails on to the next generation. The change was likely gradual over 
millions of years until, about 20 million years ago, our ancestors’ external tails disappeared 
altogether. Today, we know human embryos have tails
that dissolve as the embryo develops. But the stubby tailbone sticks around, probably because it doesn’t 
cause any harm— in fact, it serves a more minor function as the anchor point for certain 
other muscles. Up to 85% of people have a vestigial 
muscle called the “palmaris longus.” To see if you do, put your hand down on a flat surface 
and touch your pinkie to your thumb. If you see a little band pop up in the 
middle of your wrist, that’s the tendon that attaches to this 
now-defunct muscle. In this case, the fact that not everyone 
has it has helped us trace its function. Vestigial traits can persist when there’s 
no incentive to lose them— but since there’s also no incentive 
to keep them, random mutations will sometimes still
eliminate them from part of the population. Looking at our primate relatives, we can see that the palmaris longus 
is sometimes absent in those that spend more time on the land, but always present in those that spend 
more time in trees. So we think it used to help us swing 
from branch to branch, and became unnecessary when 
we moved down to land. The appendix, meanwhile, may once have 
been part of the intestinal system our ancestors used for digesting 
plant materials. As their diets changed, those parts of the
intestinal system began to shrink. Unlike other vestigial structures, though,
the appendix isn’t always harmless— it can become dangerously inflamed. For most of human history, a burst 
appendix could be a death sentence. So why did it stick around? It’s possible that it was very slowly on 
its way out, or that mutations simply hadn’t arisen 
to make it smaller. Or maybe it has other benefits— for example, it might still be a reservoir
of bacteria that helps us break down food. But the fact is, we’re not really sure why
the appendix persists. Evolution is an imperfect process. Human beings are the result of millions of
years of trial, error, and random chance— and we’re full of evolutionary relics 
to remind us of that.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is one benefit we think the appendix still serves?
Options: A. Breaks down tough plant material, B. Produces bile and acid for our stomach, C. Acts as a reservoir for helpful bacteria, D. Helps break down the sugar in dairy products
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: **Knowledge**: What is the highest possible average that would occur if every person guessed 100? Options: A. 50, B. 66.67, C. 100, D. 200 Correct Option: B
Question 2: **Comprehension**: What is the term used to describe a state where every player has chosen the best possible strategy for themselves given everyone else playing? Options: A. Nash Equilibrium, B. Common Knowledge, C. K-level Reasoning, D. Game Theory Correct Option: A
Question 3: **Application**: If the average of all guesses is 30, what number would you guess as 2/3 of the average? Options: A. 20, B. 20, C. 20, D. 20 Correct Option: B
Question 4: **Analysis**: How does the logic of the 2/3 game change when everyone comes to the same conclusion? Options: A. The highest possible logical answer gets larger., B. The highest possible logical answer stays the same., C. The highest possible logical answer gets smaller., D. The highest possible logical answer is irrelevant. Correct Option: C
Question 5: **Synthesis**: How can understanding the difference between the most logical approach and the most common affect people's behavior in the 2/3 game? Options: A. It will make people guess higher numbers., B. It will make people guess lower numbers., C. It will make people guess the same numbers., D. It will make people stop playing the game. Correct Option: B
Question 6: **Evaluation**: What is the main difference between k-level 0 and k-level 1 in the context of the 2/3 game? Options: A. K-level 0 assumes everyone else is playing at level 1, while k-level 1 assumes everyone else is playing at level 0., B. K-level 0 assumes everyone else is playing at level 0, while k-level 1 assumes everyone else is playing at level 1., C. K-level 0 assumes everyone else is playing at level 1, while k-level 1 assumes everyone else is playing at level 2., D. K-level 0 assumes everyone else is playing at level 2, while k-level 1 assumes everyone else is playing at level 3. Correct Option: B
Question 7: **Knowledge**: What is the term used to describe the tendency of people to stop at 1 or 2 k-levels? Options: A. k-level reasoning, B. common knowledge, C. game theory, D. limited thinking Correct Option: D
Question 8: **Comprehension**: How do stock traders and penalty shooters in soccer use k-level thinking? Options: A. They evaluate stocks and make decisions based on their own understanding of the situation., B. They evaluate stocks and make decisions based on what they think others will do., C. They make decisions based on their own understanding of the situation and what they think others will do., D. They make decisions based solely on what they think others will do. Correct Option: C
Question 9: **Analysis**: What is the relationship between k-level thinking and the Nash Equilibrium? Options: A. K-level thinking leads to a Nash Equilibrium., B. A Nash Equilibrium leads to k-level thinking., C. K-level thinking and the Nash Equilibrium are unrelated., D. K-level thinking can lead to a Nash Equilibrium. Correct Option: D
Question 10: **Evaluation**: What is the significance of being conscious of the tendency to stop at 1 or 2 k-levels? Options: A. It will make people guess higher numbers., B. It will make people guess lower numbers., C. It will make people adjust their expectations., D. It will make people stop playing the game. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. The generated MCQs appear to be related to game theory, k-level thinking, and Nash Equilibrium, whereas the ground truth MCQ is related to the appendix and its possible function.

However, if I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the format and style of the question, I would say that none of the generated MCQs are similar to the ground truth MCQ.

But if you insist on an answer, I would say that Question 1 is the most similar, but only because it is the first question and has a similar format, not because of any actual similarity in content or intent.

Index: None (or 1, if you insist on an answer)

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 16, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
You know that little pink thing nestled 
in the corner of your eye? It’s actually the remnant 
of a third eyelid. Known as the “plica semilunaris,” it’s much more prominent in birds 
and a few mammals, and functions like a windshield wiper 
to keep dust and debris out of their eyes. But in humans, it doesn’t work. It’s vestigial, meaning it no longer 
serves its original purpose. There are several other vestigial 
structures like the plica semilunaris in the human body. Most of these became vestigial long 
before homo sapiens existed, quietly riding along from one of 
our ancestor species to the next. But why have they stuck 
around for so long? To answer this question, it helps to 
understand natural selection. Natural selection simply means that traits which help an organism survive and 
reproduce in a given environment are more likely to make it to the 
next generation. As the environment changes, traits 
that were once useful can become harmful. Those traits are often selected against, meaning they gradually disappear 
from the population. But if a trait isn’t actively harmful, 
it might not get selected against, and stick around even 
though it isn’t useful. Take the tailbone. Evolutionary biologists think that as the 
climate got drier and grasslands popped up, our tail-bearing ancestors left the trees 
and started walking on land. The tails that had helped them 
in the trees began to disrupt their ability 
to walk on land. So individuals with mutations that reduced
the length of their tails became more successful at life on land, surviving long enough to pass their short 
tails on to the next generation. The change was likely gradual over 
millions of years until, about 20 million years ago, our ancestors’ external tails disappeared 
altogether. Today, we know human embryos have tails
that dissolve as the embryo develops. But the stubby tailbone sticks around, probably because it doesn’t 
cause any harm— in fact, it serves a more minor function as the anchor point for certain 
other muscles. Up to 85% of people have a vestigial 
muscle called the “palmaris longus.” To see if you do, put your hand down on a flat surface 
and touch your pinkie to your thumb. If you see a little band pop up in the 
middle of your wrist, that’s the tendon that attaches to this 
now-defunct muscle. In this case, the fact that not everyone 
has it has helped us trace its function. Vestigial traits can persist when there’s 
no incentive to lose them— but since there’s also no incentive 
to keep them, random mutations will sometimes still
eliminate them from part of the population. Looking at our primate relatives, we can see that the palmaris longus 
is sometimes absent in those that spend more time on the land, but always present in those that spend 
more time in trees. So we think it used to help us swing 
from branch to branch, and became unnecessary when 
we moved down to land. The appendix, meanwhile, may once have 
been part of the intestinal system our ancestors used for digesting 
plant materials. As their diets changed, those parts of the
intestinal system began to shrink. Unlike other vestigial structures, though,
the appendix isn’t always harmless— it can become dangerously inflamed. For most of human history, a burst 
appendix could be a death sentence. So why did it stick around? It’s possible that it was very slowly on 
its way out, or that mutations simply hadn’t arisen 
to make it smaller. Or maybe it has other benefits— for example, it might still be a reservoir
of bacteria that helps us break down food. But the fact is, we’re not really sure why
the appendix persists. Evolution is an imperfect process. Human beings are the result of millions of
years of trial, error, and random chance— and we’re full of evolutionary relics 
to remind us of that.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Approximately how long ago did humans lose their tails?
Options: A. 10 million years ago, B. 400,000 years ago, C. 20 million years ago, D. 2 million years ago
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
A few months ago we posed a challenge 
to our community. We asked everyone: given a range of 
integers from 0 to 100, guess the whole number closest to 2/3 
of the average of all numbers guessed. So if the average of all guesses is 60, 
the correct guess will be 40. What number do you think was the 
correct guess at 2/3 of the average? Let’s see if we can try and reason 
our way to the answer. This game is played under conditions known
to game theorists as common knowledge. Not only does every player have 
the same information — they also know that everyone else does, and that everyone else knows that 
everyone else does, and so on, infinitely. Now, the highest possible average would 
occur if every person guessed 100. In that case, 2/3 of the average 
would be 66.66. Since everyone can figure this out, it wouldn’t make sense to guess 
anything higher than 67. If everyone playing comes to 
this same conclusion, no one will guess higher than 67. Now 67 is the new highest 
possible average, so no reasonable guess should be 
higher than ⅔ of that, which is 44. This logic can be extended further 
and further. With each step, the highest possible 
logical answer keeps getting smaller. So it would seem sensible to guess the 
lowest number possible. And indeed, if everyone chose zero, the game would reach what’s known 
as a Nash Equilibrium. This is a state where every player has 
chosen the best possible strategy for themselves given 
everyone else playing, and no individual player can benefit 
by choosing differently. But, that’s not what happens 
in the real world. People, as it turns out, either aren’t 
perfectly rational, or don’t expect each other 
to be perfectly rational. Or, perhaps, it’s some combination 
of the two. When this game is played in 
real-world settings, the average tends to be somewhere 
between 20 and 35. Danish newspaper Politiken ran the game 
with over 19,000 readers participating, resulting in an average of roughly 22, 
making the correct answer 14. For our audience, the average was 31.3. So if you guessed 21 as 2/3 of 
the average, well done. Economic game theorists have a 
way of modeling this interplay between rationality and practicality 
called k-level reasoning. K stands for the number of times a 
cycle of reasoning is repeated. A person playing at k-level 0 would 
approach our game naively, guessing a number at random without 
thinking about the other players. At k-level 1, a player would assume 
everyone else was playing at level 0, resulting in an average of 50, 
and thus guess 33. At k-level 2, they’d assume that everyone 
else was playing at level 1, leading them to guess 22. It would take 12 k-levels to reach 0. The evidence suggests that most 
people stop at 1 or 2 k-levels. And that’s useful to know, because k-level thinking comes into 
play in high-stakes situations. For example, stock traders evaluate stocks
not only based on earnings reports, but also on the value that others 
place on those numbers. And during penalty kicks in soccer, both the shooter and the goalie decide 
whether to go right or left based on what they think the other 
person is thinking. Goalies often memorize the patterns of 
their opponents ahead of time, but penalty shooters know that 
and can plan accordingly. In each case, participants must weigh 
their own understanding of the best course of action against how 
well they think other participants understand the situation. But 1 or 2 k-levels is by no means 
a hard and fast rule— simply being conscious of this tendency 
can make people adjust their expectations. For instance, what would happen 
if people played the 2/3 game after understanding the difference between
the most logical approach and the most common? Submit your own guess at what 2/3 
of the new average will be by using the form below, and we’ll find out.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: If you think your opponents are playing at level-3, then you want to play at level:
Options: A. 3, B. 2, C. 4, D. 0
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: **Knowledge** Options: A. The world of the gods was made of mountains and deserts., B. The world of the gods, made of fields, plains and gardens., C. The supreme spirit was named Yaya., D. The brothers were born in the earthly realm. Correct Option: B
Question 2: **Comprehension** Options: A. Deminan was a caracaracol because he was born with a disease., B. Deminan and his brothers were separated from the celestial lands by a giant gourd., C. The world of seas was formed by the tears of the Earth Mother Goddess., D. The caracaracols were cursed to suffer from the illness that marked Deminan. Correct Option: D
Question 3: **Application** Options: A. A caracaracol is someone who is able to communicate with animals., B. A caracaracol is someone who can maintain the balance between people and gods., C. A caracaracol is a person with a special gift from the gods., D. A caracaracol is someone who is able to heal others. Correct Option: B
Question 4: **Analysis** Options: A. The brothers were separated from the celestial lands because of a curse., B. The brothers were separated from the celestial lands because of a deluge., C. The world of seas was formed by the waters from the gourd., D. The caracaracols were created by the Earth Mother Goddess. Correct Option: C
Question 5: **Synthesis** Options: A. The caracaracols were created to maintain the balance between people and animals., B. The caracaracols were created to be a link between the celestial and earthly realms., C. The caracaracols were created to communicate with the gods., D. The caracaracols were created to be a source of healing. Correct Option: B
Question 6: **Evaluation** Options: A. The curse of Deminan's disease is a blessing in disguise., B. The caracaracols are a necessary part of the world of humans., C. The caracaracols are a burden to the world of humans., D. The caracaracols are a threat to the balance between people and gods. Correct Option: B
Question 7: **Knowledge** Options: A. Bayamanacao was the father of Deminan and his brothers., B. Bayamanacao was the grandfather of Deminan and his brothers., C. Bayamanacao was the brother of Deminan and his brothers., D. Bayamanacao was a friend of Deminan and his brothers. Correct Option: B
Question 8: **Comprehension** Options: A. The caracaracols were created by Deminan and his brothers., B. The caracaracols were created by Bayamanacao., C. The caracaracols were a result of a curse., D. The caracaracols were a gift from the gods. Correct Option: C
Question 9: **Application** Options: A. A caracaracol is someone who is able to communicate with the gods., B. A caracaracol is someone who can maintain the balance between people and animals., C. A caracaracol is a person with a special gift from the gods., D. A caracaracol is someone who is able to heal others. Correct Option: A
Question 10: **Evaluation** Options: A. The caracaracols are a positive force in the world of humans., B. The caracaracols are a necessary part of the world of humans., C. The caracaracols are a burden to the world of humans., D. The caracaracols are a threat to the balance between people and gods. Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. However, I will provide the index of the least dissimilar generated MCQ.

The ground truth MCQ is about k-level reasoning, where the question asks about the level at which a person should play if they think their opponents are playing at level 3. The correct answer is level 4.

The generated MCQs are about a completely different topic, but if I had to choose the least dissimilar one, I would say it's Question 5: **Synthesis**. This question talks about the creation of "caracaracols" to be a link between the celestial and earthly realms, which involves some level of hierarchical thinking, similar to k-level reasoning. However, the question intent, options, and content are still very different from the ground truth MCQ.

Index of the least dissimilar generated MCQ: 5

Please note that this is a very weak match, and it would be better to generate new MCQs that are more relevant to the topic of k-level reasoning.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
A few months ago we posed a challenge 
to our community. We asked everyone: given a range of 
integers from 0 to 100, guess the whole number closest to 2/3 
of the average of all numbers guessed. So if the average of all guesses is 60, 
the correct guess will be 40. What number do you think was the 
correct guess at 2/3 of the average? Let’s see if we can try and reason 
our way to the answer. This game is played under conditions known
to game theorists as common knowledge. Not only does every player have 
the same information — they also know that everyone else does, and that everyone else knows that 
everyone else does, and so on, infinitely. Now, the highest possible average would 
occur if every person guessed 100. In that case, 2/3 of the average 
would be 66.66. Since everyone can figure this out, it wouldn’t make sense to guess 
anything higher than 67. If everyone playing comes to 
this same conclusion, no one will guess higher than 67. Now 67 is the new highest 
possible average, so no reasonable guess should be 
higher than ⅔ of that, which is 44. This logic can be extended further 
and further. With each step, the highest possible 
logical answer keeps getting smaller. So it would seem sensible to guess the 
lowest number possible. And indeed, if everyone chose zero, the game would reach what’s known 
as a Nash Equilibrium. This is a state where every player has 
chosen the best possible strategy for themselves given 
everyone else playing, and no individual player can benefit 
by choosing differently. But, that’s not what happens 
in the real world. People, as it turns out, either aren’t 
perfectly rational, or don’t expect each other 
to be perfectly rational. Or, perhaps, it’s some combination 
of the two. When this game is played in 
real-world settings, the average tends to be somewhere 
between 20 and 35. Danish newspaper Politiken ran the game 
with over 19,000 readers participating, resulting in an average of roughly 22, 
making the correct answer 14. For our audience, the average was 31.3. So if you guessed 21 as 2/3 of 
the average, well done. Economic game theorists have a 
way of modeling this interplay between rationality and practicality 
called k-level reasoning. K stands for the number of times a 
cycle of reasoning is repeated. A person playing at k-level 0 would 
approach our game naively, guessing a number at random without 
thinking about the other players. At k-level 1, a player would assume 
everyone else was playing at level 0, resulting in an average of 50, 
and thus guess 33. At k-level 2, they’d assume that everyone 
else was playing at level 1, leading them to guess 22. It would take 12 k-levels to reach 0. The evidence suggests that most 
people stop at 1 or 2 k-levels. And that’s useful to know, because k-level thinking comes into 
play in high-stakes situations. For example, stock traders evaluate stocks
not only based on earnings reports, but also on the value that others 
place on those numbers. And during penalty kicks in soccer, both the shooter and the goalie decide 
whether to go right or left based on what they think the other 
person is thinking. Goalies often memorize the patterns of 
their opponents ahead of time, but penalty shooters know that 
and can plan accordingly. In each case, participants must weigh 
their own understanding of the best course of action against how 
well they think other participants understand the situation. But 1 or 2 k-levels is by no means 
a hard and fast rule— simply being conscious of this tendency 
can make people adjust their expectations. For instance, what would happen 
if people played the 2/3 game after understanding the difference between
the most logical approach and the most common? Submit your own guess at what 2/3 
of the new average will be by using the form below, and we’ll find out.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: You play a version of the 2/3 game where the best guess is the person who guesses 1/2 the average of all guesses from 0 to 100. You guess 6.25. You played at level:
Options: A. 2, B. 3, C. 4, D. 5
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:

Question 3: **Application** Options: A. A caracaracol is someone who is able to communicate with animals., B. A caracaracol is someone who can maintain the balance between people and gods., C. A caracaracol is a person with a special gift from the gods., D. A caracaracol is someone who is able to heal others. Correct Option: B
Question 4: **Analysis** Options: A. The brothers were separated from the celestial lands because of a curse., B. The brothers were separated from the celestial lands because of a deluge., C. The world of seas was formed by the waters from the gourd., D. The caracaracols were created by the Earth Mother Goddess. Correct Option: C
Question 5: **Synthesis** Options: A. The caracaracols were created to maintain the balance between people and animals., B. The caracaracols were created to be a link between the celestial and earthly realms., C. The caracaracols were created to communicate with the gods., D. The caracaracols were created to be a source of healing. Correct Option: B
Question 6: **Evaluation** Options: A. The curse of Deminan's disease is a blessing in disguise., B. The caracaracols are a necessary part of the world of humans., C. The caracaracols are a burden to the world of humans., D. The caracaracols are a threat to the balance between people and gods. Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
A few months ago we posed a challenge 
to our community. We asked everyone: given a range of 
integers from 0 to 100, guess the whole number closest to 2/3 
of the average of all numbers guessed. So if the average of all guesses is 60, 
the correct guess will be 40. What number do you think was the 
correct guess at 2/3 of the average? Let’s see if we can try and reason 
our way to the answer. This game is played under conditions known
to game theorists as common knowledge. Not only does every player have 
the same information — they also know that everyone else does, and that everyone else knows that 
everyone else does, and so on, infinitely. Now, the highest possible average would 
occur if every person guessed 100. In that case, 2/3 of the average 
would be 66.66. Since everyone can figure this out, it wouldn’t make sense to guess 
anything higher than 67. If everyone playing comes to 
this same conclusion, no one will guess higher than 67. Now 67 is the new highest 
possible average, so no reasonable guess should be 
higher than ⅔ of that, which is 44. This logic can be extended further 
and further. With each step, the highest possible 
logical answer keeps getting smaller. So it would seem sensible to guess the 
lowest number possible. And indeed, if everyone chose zero, the game would reach what’s known 
as a Nash Equilibrium. This is a state where every player has 
chosen the best possible strategy for themselves given 
everyone else playing, and no individual player can benefit 
by choosing differently. But, that’s not what happens 
in the real world. People, as it turns out, either aren’t 
perfectly rational, or don’t expect each other 
to be perfectly rational. Or, perhaps, it’s some combination 
of the two. When this game is played in 
real-world settings, the average tends to be somewhere 
between 20 and 35. Danish newspaper Politiken ran the game 
with over 19,000 readers participating, resulting in an average of roughly 22, 
making the correct answer 14. For our audience, the average was 31.3. So if you guessed 21 as 2/3 of 
the average, well done. Economic game theorists have a 
way of modeling this interplay between rationality and practicality 
called k-level reasoning. K stands for the number of times a 
cycle of reasoning is repeated. A person playing at k-level 0 would 
approach our game naively, guessing a number at random without 
thinking about the other players. At k-level 1, a player would assume 
everyone else was playing at level 0, resulting in an average of 50, 
and thus guess 33. At k-level 2, they’d assume that everyone 
else was playing at level 1, leading them to guess 22. It would take 12 k-levels to reach 0. The evidence suggests that most 
people stop at 1 or 2 k-levels. And that’s useful to know, because k-level thinking comes into 
play in high-stakes situations. For example, stock traders evaluate stocks
not only based on earnings reports, but also on the value that others 
place on those numbers. And during penalty kicks in soccer, both the shooter and the goalie decide 
whether to go right or left based on what they think the other 
person is thinking. Goalies often memorize the patterns of 
their opponents ahead of time, but penalty shooters know that 
and can plan accordingly. In each case, participants must weigh 
their own understanding of the best course of action against how 
well they think other participants understand the situation. But 1 or 2 k-levels is by no means 
a hard and fast rule— simply being conscious of this tendency 
can make people adjust their expectations. For instance, what would happen 
if people played the 2/3 game after understanding the difference between
the most logical approach and the most common? Submit your own guess at what 2/3 
of the new average will be by using the form below, and we’ll find out.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Stock brokers must think in k-levels because:
Options: A. They don’t know what companies are really up to., B. They don’t know what the future will bring., C. Their valuation of a company depends on uncertainty at the firm level., D. Their valuation of a company depends on how others value that company.
Correct Option: D

Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. **Transcript**:
A few months ago we posed a challenge 
to our community. We asked everyone: given a range of 
integers from 0 to 100, guess the whole number closest to 2/3 
of the average of all numbers guessed. So if the average of all guesses is 60, 
the correct guess will be 40. What number do you think was the 
correct guess at 2/3 of the average? Let’s see if we can try and reason 
our way to the answer. This game is played under conditions known
to game theorists as common knowledge. Not only does every player have 
the same information — they also know that everyone else does, and that everyone else knows that 
everyone else does, and so on, infinitely. Now, the highest possible average would 
occur if every person guessed 100. In that case, 2/3 of the average 
would be 66.66. Since everyone can figure this out, it wouldn’t make sense to guess 
anything higher than 67. If everyone playing comes to 
this same conclusion, no one will guess higher than 67. Now 67 is the new highest 
possible average, so no reasonable guess should be 
higher than ⅔ of that, which is 44. This logic can be extended further 
and further. With each step, the highest possible 
logical answer keeps getting smaller. So it would seem sensible to guess the 
lowest number possible. And indeed, if everyone chose zero, the game would reach what’s known 
as a Nash Equilibrium. This is a state where every player has 
chosen the best possible strategy for themselves given 
everyone else playing, and no individual player can benefit 
by choosing differently. But, that’s not what happens 
in the real world. People, as it turns out, either aren’t 
perfectly rational, or don’t expect each other 
to be perfectly rational. Or, perhaps, it’s some combination 
of the two. When this game is played in 
real-world settings, the average tends to be somewhere 
between 20 and 35. Danish newspaper Politiken ran the game 
with over 19,000 readers participating, resulting in an average of roughly 22, 
making the correct answer 14. For our audience, the average was 31.3. So if you guessed 21 as 2/3 of 
the average, well done. Economic game theorists have a 
way of modeling this interplay between rationality and practicality 
called k-level reasoning. K stands for the number of times a 
cycle of reasoning is repeated. A person playing at k-level 0 would 
approach our game naively, guessing a number at random without 
thinking about the other players. At k-level 1, a player would assume 
everyone else was playing at level 0, resulting in an average of 50, 
and thus guess 33. At k-level 2, they’d assume that everyone 
else was playing at level 1, leading them to guess 22. It would take 12 k-levels to reach 0. The evidence suggests that most 
people stop at 1 or 2 k-levels. And that’s useful to know, because k-level thinking comes into 
play in high-stakes situations. For example, stock traders evaluate stocks
not only based on earnings reports, but also on the value that others 
place on those numbers. And during penalty kicks in soccer, both the shooter and the goalie decide 
whether to go right or left based on what they think the other 
person is thinking. Goalies often memorize the patterns of 
their opponents ahead of time, but penalty shooters know that 
and can plan accordingly. In each case, participants must weigh 
their own understanding of the best course of action against how 
well they think other participants understand the situation. But 1 or 2 k-levels is by no means 
a hard and fast rule— simply being conscious of this tendency 
can make people adjust their expectations. For instance, what would happen 
if people played the 2/3 game after understanding the difference between
the most logical approach and the most common? Submit your own guess at what 2/3 
of the new average will be by using the form below, and we’ll find out.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Your phone dies but you were supposed to meet up with a good friend at one of two locations across the city by 7pm. You were supposed to mutually confirm with them a location. Under what scenarios do you need to apply k-level reasoning?
Options: A. Your friend is nice and knows your favorite spot., B. Your friend is mean and you know her favorite spot., C. Your friend told you where she would like last week, but she is forgetful., D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: A Nash equilibrium is when:
Options: A. You can’t do any better than your current strategy., B. You and your opponent can mutually never do better than the current strategies., C. Like a cartel, you coordinate even though cheating on the arrangement is lucrative., D. All of the above.
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Before the world of humans began, there was the world of the gods, 
made of fields, plains and gardens. Four brothers wandered this 
celestial realm. They had no family other 
than each other— they didn’t even know who 
their parents were. One of the brothers, Deminan, 
looked different from the others. His skin was covered in painful scabs, and he wondered why he alone had 
been marked with this affliction. One day, while the supreme spirit 
Yaya was out in his gardens, Deminan and his brothers snuck 
into Yaya’s house. After feasting and exploring, they spotted
a giant gourd hanging in the corner. But as they tried to look inside 
the gourd, they dropped it. The gourd broke apart, releasing a deluge 
that swept the brothers away, separating them from the 
celestial lands forever. The waters from the gourd 
formed a new world. This realm was covered in seas, 
which didn’t exist in the gods’ world. The waters were full of fish 
and other creatures, and dotted with islands and caves. This world of seas was also cut off 
completely from the celestial realm, and the brothers wandered aimlessly, even more lost than they had been before. One day, three of the brothers 
stumbled upon a house. In the house lived an elder named 
Bayamanacao, and he invited them in. When Deminan caught up slightly later, 
he followed them into the house. Bayamanacao told the brothers 
he was their grandfather and gave them a gift of special 
cassava bread. He revealed their family lineage to them: their mother had been the Earth Mother 
Goddess Itibi Cahubaba and had died when they were born. The brothers were grateful for his 
hospitality and insight into their past. But then Bayamanacao turned on Deminan, blowing tobacco spittle from his nose 
onto Deminan’s back. The spot where the spittle landed 
immediately began to swell and sting. Soon Deminan was delirious and his back was so swollen his 
brothers feared he would die. Not knowing what else to do, 
they cut open the welt. A turtle emerged from the 
wound and swam away, alternating easily between sea 
and land as she went. When Deminan recovered from his delirium, he finally understood what the 
curse of his disease meant: he was a caracaracol, 
able to communicate with the gods. He was the link between the celestial 
realm and the earthly realm. Deminan was the first in a long 
lineage of caracaracols. The world of seas he and his brothers 
had created when they dropped the gourd became the world of humans, where the caracaracols who followed 
Deminan maintained the delicate balance between people and gods. But their unique power came at a price: Deminan and all the caracaracols 
who followed him continued to suffer from the illness that 
had first marked Deminan as special. Represented in Taino carvings 
and figurines with a swollen back and emaciated arms, the caracaracol is both cursed and blessed
to be a conduit between worlds.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Deminán had how many brothers?
Options: A. one, B. two, C. three, D. four
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the main goal of Adam Weishaupt's secret society, the Illuminati? Options: A. To spread Catholicism throughout Bavaria, B. To promote secular philosophy and universal human rights, C. To overthrow the Bavarian government, D. To join forces with the Freemasons Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the name of the code name that Adam Weishaupt adopted for himself? Options: A. Spartacus, B. Illuminus, C. Areopagus, D. Knigge Correct Option: A
Question 3: Which of the following best describes the relationship between the Illuminati and the Freemasons? Options: A. The Illuminati was a rival to the Freemasons, B. The Illuminati was a branch of the Freemasons, C. The Illuminati and Freemasons shared similar ideals and recruited from each other's ranks, D. The Illuminati was formed to counter the influence of the Freemasons Correct Option: C
Question 4: According to the transcript, what was the outcome of the 1784 decree by Duke Karl Theodor of Bavaria? Options: A. The Illuminati was allowed to continue operating, B. The Illuminati was forced to go underground, C. The Illuminati was banned and its records were seized, D. The Illuminati was merged with the Freemasons Correct Option: C
Question 5: What was the impact of the Illuminati's dissolution on the spread of its ideas? Options: A. The ideas were completely forgotten, B. The ideas continued to spread through other secret societies, C. The ideas were adopted by Western governments and continue to influence them today, D. The ideas were only influential in the United States Correct Option: C
Question 6: What was the basis for the conservative authors' claim that the Illuminati survived their banishment and orchestrated the overthrow of the monarchy? Options: A. The existence of Illuminati records, B. The influence of the Illuminati on the French Revolution, C. The promotion of similar ideas by preacher Jedidiah Morse, D. The overlap between Illuminati and Freemasons records Correct Option: C
Question 7: What was the role of Baron Adolph Knigge in the Illuminati? Options: A. He was a founder of the Illuminati, B. He was a member of the Illuminati's ruling council, C. He was an influential recruiter for the Illuminati, D. He was a rival to Adam Weishaupt Correct Option: C
Question 8: What was the main difference between the Illuminati and the Freemasons, according to the transcript? Options: A. The Illuminati was more secretive than the Freemasons, B. The Illuminati was more exclusive than the Freemasons, C. The Illuminati believed in keeping religion separate from governance, while the Freemasons did not, D. The Illuminati was formed to counter the influence of the Freemasons Correct Option: C
Question 9: What was the outcome of the Illuminati's dissolution in terms of its existence? Options: A. The Illuminati continued to exist in secret, B. The Illuminati was forced into exile, C. The Illuminati no longer exists, D. The Illuminati was merged with the Freemasons Correct Option: C
Question 10: What was the significance of the Illuminati's brief existence in the context of the spread of its ideas? Options: A. The Illuminati's ideas were completely forgotten after its dissolution, B. The Illuminati's ideas were only influential in Bavaria, C. The Illuminati's ideas became the basis for many Western governments today, D. The Illuminati's ideas were only influential in the United States Correct Option: C
Question 11: What was the reason for the suspicious Bavarian government to keep records of alleged members of the Illuminati? Options: A. They believed the Illuminati was a threat to national security, B. They believed the Illuminati was a rival to the Freemasons, C. They believed the Illuminati was undermining the people's religious faith, D. They believed the Illuminati was a threat to the monarchy Correct Option: C
Question 12: What was the impact of the Illuminati's dissolution on Adam Weishaupt? Options: A. He became a prominent figure in the Freemasons, B. He was forced into exile, C. He continued to promote the ideas of the Illuminati, D. He was killed in a duel Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Before the world of humans began, there was the world of the gods, 
made of fields, plains and gardens. Four brothers wandered this 
celestial realm. They had no family other 
than each other— they didn’t even know who 
their parents were. One of the brothers, Deminan, 
looked different from the others. His skin was covered in painful scabs, and he wondered why he alone had 
been marked with this affliction. One day, while the supreme spirit 
Yaya was out in his gardens, Deminan and his brothers snuck 
into Yaya’s house. After feasting and exploring, they spotted
a giant gourd hanging in the corner. But as they tried to look inside 
the gourd, they dropped it. The gourd broke apart, releasing a deluge 
that swept the brothers away, separating them from the 
celestial lands forever. The waters from the gourd 
formed a new world. This realm was covered in seas, 
which didn’t exist in the gods’ world. The waters were full of fish 
and other creatures, and dotted with islands and caves. This world of seas was also cut off 
completely from the celestial realm, and the brothers wandered aimlessly, even more lost than they had been before. One day, three of the brothers 
stumbled upon a house. In the house lived an elder named 
Bayamanacao, and he invited them in. When Deminan caught up slightly later, 
he followed them into the house. Bayamanacao told the brothers 
he was their grandfather and gave them a gift of special 
cassava bread. He revealed their family lineage to them: their mother had been the Earth Mother 
Goddess Itibi Cahubaba and had died when they were born. The brothers were grateful for his 
hospitality and insight into their past. But then Bayamanacao turned on Deminan, blowing tobacco spittle from his nose 
onto Deminan’s back. The spot where the spittle landed 
immediately began to swell and sting. Soon Deminan was delirious and his back was so swollen his 
brothers feared he would die. Not knowing what else to do, 
they cut open the welt. A turtle emerged from the 
wound and swam away, alternating easily between sea 
and land as she went. When Deminan recovered from his delirium, he finally understood what the 
curse of his disease meant: he was a caracaracol, 
able to communicate with the gods. He was the link between the celestial 
realm and the earthly realm. Deminan was the first in a long 
lineage of caracaracols. The world of seas he and his brothers 
had created when they dropped the gourd became the world of humans, where the caracaracols who followed 
Deminan maintained the delicate balance between people and gods. But their unique power came at a price: Deminan and all the caracaracols 
who followed him continued to suffer from the illness that 
had first marked Deminan as special. Represented in Taino carvings 
and figurines with a swollen back and emaciated arms, the caracaracol is both cursed and blessed
to be a conduit between worlds.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: When the welt on Deminán’s back was cut open, what came out?
Options: A. a frog, B. a snake, C. a bird, D. a turtle
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:

The Illuminati was formed to counter the influence of the Freemasons Correct Option: C

They believed the Illuminati was a threat to national security, B. They believed the Illuminati was a rival to the Freemasons, C. Before the world of humans began, there was the world of the gods, 
made of fields, plains and gardens. Four brothers wandered this 
celestial realm. They had no family other 
than each other— they didn’t even know who 
their parents were. One of the brothers, Deminan, 
looked different from the others. His skin was covered in painful scabs, and he wondered why he alone had 
been marked with this affliction. One day, while the supreme spirit 
Yaya was out in his gardens, Deminan and his brothers snuck 
into Yaya’s house. After feasting and exploring, they spotted
a giant gourd hanging in the corner. But as they tried to look inside 
the gourd, they dropped it. The gourd broke apart, releasing a deluge 
that swept the brothers away, separating them from the 
celestial lands forever. The waters from the gourd 
formed a new world. This realm was covered in seas, 
which didn’t exist in the gods’ world. The waters were full of fish 
and other creatures, and dotted with islands and caves. This world of seas was also cut off 
completely from the celestial realm, and the brothers wandered aimlessly, even more lost than they had been before. One day, three of the brothers 
stumbled upon a house. In the house lived an elder named 
Bayamanacao, and he invited them in. When Deminan caught up slightly later, 
he followed them into the house. Bayamanacao told the brothers 
he was their grandfather and gave them a gift of special 
cassava bread. He revealed their family lineage to them: their mother had been the Earth Mother 
Goddess Itibi Cahubaba and had died when they were born. The brothers were grateful for his 
hospitality and insight into their past. But then Bayamanacao turned on Deminan, blowing tobacco spittle from his nose 
onto Deminan’s back. The spot where the spittle landed 
immediately began to swell and sting. Soon Deminan was delirious and his back was so swollen his 
brothers feared he would die. Not knowing what else to do, 
they cut open the welt. A turtle emerged from the 
wound and swam away, alternating easily between sea 
and land as she went. When Deminan recovered from his delirium, he finally understood what the 
curse of his disease meant: he was a caracaracol,

realm and the earthly realm. Deminan was the first in a long

Deminan maintained the delicate balance between people and gods. But their unique power came at a price: Deminan and all the caracaracols 
who followed him continued to suffer from the illness that 
had first marked Deminan as special. Represented in Taino carvings 
and figurines with a swollen back and emaciated arms, the caracaracol is both cursed and blessed
to be a conduit between worlds.

Before the world of humans began, there was the world of the gods, 
made of fields, plains and gardens. Four brothers wandered this

their parents were. One of the brothers, Deminan,

Matching Prompt:

Before the world of humans began, there was the world of the gods, 
made of fields, plains and gardens. Four brothers wandered this 
celestial realm. They had no family other 
than each other— they didn’t even know who 
their parents were. One of the brothers, Deminan, 
looked different from the others. His skin was covered in painful scabs, and he wondered why he alone had 
been marked with this affliction. One day, while the supreme spirit 
Yaya was out in his gardens, Deminan and his brothers snuck 
into Yaya’s house. After feasting and exploring, they spotted
a giant gourd hanging in the corner. But as they tried to look inside 
the gourd, they dropped it. The gourd broke apart, releasing a deluge 
that swept the brothers away, separating them from the 
celestial lands forever. The waters from the gourd 
formed a new world. This realm was covered in seas, 
which didn’t exist in the gods’ world. The waters were full of fish 
and other creatures, and dotted with islands and caves. This world of seas was also cut off 
completely from the celestial realm, and the brothers wandered aimlessly, even more lost than they had been before. One day, three of the brothers 
stumbled upon a house. In the house lived an elder named 
Bayamanacao, and he invited them in. When Deminan caught up slightly later, 
he followed them into the house. Bayamanacao told the brothers 
he was their grandfather and gave them a gift of special 
cassava bread. He revealed their family lineage to them: their mother had been the Earth Mother 
Goddess Itibi Cahubaba and had died when they were born. The brothers were grateful for his 
hospitality and insight into their past. But then Bayamanacao turned on Deminan, blowing tobacco spittle from his nose 
onto Deminan’s back. The spot where the spittle landed 
immediately began to swell and sting. Soon Deminan was delirious and his back was so swollen his 
brothers feared he would die. Not knowing what else to do, 
they cut open the welt. A turtle emerged from the 
wound and swam away, alternating easily between sea 
and land as she went. When Deminan recovered from his delirium, he finally understood what the 
curse of his disease meant: he was a caracaracol, 
able to communicate with the gods. He was the link between the celestial 
realm and the earthly realm. Deminan was the first in a long 
lineage of caracaracols. The world of seas he and his brothers 
had created when they dropped the gourd became the world of humans, where the caracaracols who followed 
Deminan maintained the delicate balance between people and gods. But their unique power came at a price: Deminan and all the caracaracols 
who followed him continued to suffer from the illness that 
had first marked Deminan as special. Represented in Taino carvings 
and figurines with a swollen back and emaciated arms, the caracaracol is both cursed and blessed
to be a conduit between worlds.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What special gift does a caracaracol have?
Options: A. they are immortal, B. they do not need to eat, C. they can communicate with the gods, D. they sleep during the day
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the main goal of Adam Weishaupt's secret society, the Illuminati? Options: A. To spread Catholicism throughout Bavaria, B. To promote secular philosophy and universal human rights, C. To overthrow the Bavarian government, D. To join forces with the Freemasons Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the name of the code name that Adam Weishaupt adopted for himself? Options: A. Spartacus, B. Illuminus, C. Areopagus, D. Knigge Correct Option: A
Question 3: Which of the following best describes the relationship between the Illuminati and the Freemasons? Options: A. The Illuminati was a rival to the Freemasons, B. The Illuminati was a branch of the Freemasons, C. The Illuminati and Freemasons shared similar ideals and recruited from each other's ranks, D. The Illuminati was formed to counter the influence of the Freemasons Correct Option: C
Question 4: According to the transcript, what was the outcome of the 1784 decree by Duke Karl Theodor of Bavaria? Options: A. The Illuminati was allowed to continue operating, B. The Illuminati was forced to go underground, C. The Illuminati was banned and its records were seized, D. The Illuminati was merged with the Freemasons Correct Option: C
Question 5: What was the impact of the Illuminati's dissolution on the spread of its ideas? Options: A. The ideas were completely forgotten, B. The ideas continued to spread through other secret societies, C. The ideas were adopted by Western governments and continue to influence them today, D. The ideas were only influential in the United States Correct Option: C
Question 6: What was the basis for the conservative authors' claim that the Illuminati survived their banishment and orchestrated the overthrow of the monarchy? Options: A. The existence of Illuminati records, B. The influence of the Illuminati on the French Revolution, C. The promotion of similar ideas by preacher Jedidiah Morse, D. The overlap between Illuminati and Freemasons records Correct Option: C
Question 7: What was the role of Baron Adolph Knigge in the Illuminati? Options: A. He was a founder of the Illuminati, B. He was a member of the Illuminati's ruling council, C. He was an influential recruiter for the Illuminati, D. He was a rival to Adam Weishaupt Correct Option: C
Question 8: What was the main difference between the Illuminati and the Freemasons, according to the transcript? Options: A. The Illuminati was more secretive than the Freemasons, B. The Illuminati was more exclusive than the Freemasons, C. The Illuminati believed in keeping religion separate from governance, while the Freemasons did not, D. The Illuminati was formed to counter the influence of the Freemasons Correct Option: C
Question 9: What was the outcome of the Illuminati's dissolution in terms of its existence? Options: A. The Illuminati continued to exist in secret, B. The Illuminati was forced into exile, C. The Illuminati no longer exists, D. The Illuminati was merged with the Freemasons Correct Option: C
Question 10: What was the significance of the Illuminati's brief existence in the context of the spread of its ideas? Options: A. The Illuminati's ideas were completely forgotten after its dissolution, B. The Illuminati's ideas were only influential in Bavaria, C. The Illuminati's ideas became the basis for many Western governments today, D. The Illuminati's ideas were only influential in the United States Correct Option: C
Question 11: What was the reason for the suspicious Bavarian government to keep records of alleged members of the Illuminati? Options: A. They believed the Illuminati was a threat to national security, B. They believed the Illuminati was a rival to the Freemasons, C. They believed the Illuminati was undermining the people's religious faith, D. They believed the Illuminati was a threat to the monarchy Correct Option: C
Question 12: What was the impact of the Illuminati's dissolution on Adam Weishaupt? Options: A. He became a prominent figure in the Freemasons, B. He was forced into exile, C. He continued to promote the ideas of the Illuminati, D. He was killed in a duel Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The year was 1776. In Bavaria, new ideals of rationalism, 
religious freedom, and universal human rights competed with the Catholic church’s 
heavy influence over public affairs. Across the Atlantic, a new nation staked its claim for 
independence on the basis of these ideas. But back in Bavaria, law professor Adam Weishaupt’s 
attempts to teach secular philosophy continued to be frustrated. Weishaupt decided to spread his ideas 
through a secret society that would shine a light on the 
shortcomings of the Church’s ideology. He called his secret society 
the Illuminati. Weishaupt modelled aspects of his secret 
society off a group called the Freemasons. Originally an elite stoneworkers’ 
guild in the late Middle Ages, the Freemasons had gone from passing 
down the craft of masonry to more generally promoting ideals of 
knowledge and reason. Over time, they had grown into a 
semi-secret, exclusive order that included many wealthy and 
influential individuals, with elaborate, secret initiation rituals. Weishaupt created his parallel 
society while also joining the Freemasons and recruiting from their ranks. He adopted the code name 
Spartacus for himself, after the famed leader of the 
Roman slave revolt. Early members became the Illuminati’s 
ruling council, or Areopagus. One of these members, Baron Adolph 
Knigge, was also a freemason, and became an influential recruiter. With Knigge’s help, the Illuminati 
expanded their numbers, gained influence within 
several Masonic chapters, and incorporated Masonic rituals. By 1784, there were over 600 members, including influential scholars 
and politicians. As the Illuminati gained members, the American Revolution also 
gained momentum. Thomas Jefferson would later cite 
Weishaupt as an inspiration. European monarchs and clergy were fearful 
of similar revolts on their home soil. Meanwhile, the existence of the Illuminati
had become an open secret. Both the Illuminati and the Freemasons 
drew exclusively from society’s wealthy elite, which meant they were constantly 
rubbing shoulders with members of the religious and 
political establishment. Many in the government and church 
believed that both groups were determined to undermine the 
people’s religious faith. But these groups didn’t necessarily 
oppose religion— they just believed it should be kept 
separate from governance. Still, the suspicious Bavarian government 
started keeping records of alleged members of the Illuminati. Just as Illuminati members begun to secure
important positions in local governments and universities, a 1784 decree by Duke Karl Theodor 
of Bavaria banned all secret societies. While a public ban on something ostensibly
secret might seem difficult to enforce, in this case it worked. Only nine years after its founding, the group dissolved, 
their records were seized, and Weishaupt forced into exile. The Illuminati would become more 
notorious in their afterlife than they had ever been in 
their brief existence. A decade later, in the aftermath 
of the French Revolution, conservative authors claimed the 
Illuminati had survived their banishment and orchestrated the overthrow 
of the monarchy. In the United States, preacher Jedidiah Morse promoted 
similar ideas of an Illuminati conspiracy against the government. But though the idea of a secret group 
orchestrating political upheaval is still alive and well today, there is no
evidence that the Illuminati survived, reformed, or went underground. Their brief tenure is well-documented 
in Bavarian government records, the still-active Freemasons’s records, and particularly the overlap between 
these two sources, without a whisper since. In the spirit of rationalism the 
Illuminati embraced, one must conclude they no longer exist. But the ideas that spurred Weishaupt 
to found the illuminati still spread, becoming the basis for many Western 
governments today. These ideas didn’t start or end 
with the Illuminati— instead, it was one community that 
represented a wave of change that was already underway 
when it was founded and continued long after it ended.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The Illuminati's ruling council were known as the:
Options: A. Parliamentarians, B. Areopagus, C. Spartacus, D. The chamber
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary difference between the keratin coverings of claws and nails? Options: A. The shape of the bone at the end of the animal's digits, B. The amount of keratin produced by the keratin matrix, C. The type of protein used to make the keratin, D. The rate at which the keratinocytes grow Correct Option: A
Question 2: What is the name of the protein that makes up both claws and nails? Options: A. Collagen, B. Keratin, C. Elastin, D. Fibronectin Correct Option: B
Question 3: According to the transcript, what is the main advantage of nails over claws for primates? Options: A. They are sharper and more effective for hunting, B. They provide a rigid surface to press against, improving grip and sensitivity, C. They are easier to retract and extend, D. They are less likely to get damaged Correct Option: B
Question 4: How do nails improve the sensitivity of a primate's digits? Options: A. By providing a softer surface to detect changes in pressure, B. By providing an extra surface to detect changes in pressure, C. By reducing the amount of keratin produced, D. By increasing the rate at which the keratinocytes grow Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the likely reason why nails have persisted as an adaptation in primates? Options: A. They are more effective for hunting than claws, B. They provide a rigid surface to press against, improving grip and sensitivity, C. They are easier to retract and extend, D. They are less likely to get damaged Correct Option: B
Question 6: How do the evolution of nails and the evolution of opposable thumbs and toes relate to each other? Options: A. They are independent adaptations, B. They are closely linked and have a common purpose, C. They are mutually exclusive and cannot coexist, D. They are not related at all Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is an example of an unexpected way that claws are used in the animal kingdom? Options: A. Manatees use nails to grasp their food, B. Researchers think elephant toenails may sense vibrations in the ground to help them hear, C. Some primates, like the aye-ayes of Madagascar, have re-acquired claws, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 8: What is the likely reason why claws are not as effective for primates as nails? Options: A. They are sharper and more effective for hunting, B. They provide a rigid surface to press against, improving grip and sensitivity, C. Their points make grabbing difficult and potentially dangerous, D. They are easier to retract and extend Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the main advantage of nails over claws for primates in terms of their ability to create and wield complex tools? Options: A. They are sharper and more effective for hunting, B. They provide a rigid surface to press against, improving grip and sensitivity, C. Their points make grabbing difficult and potentially dangerous, D. They are easier to retract and extend Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the likely reason why the evolution of nails and the evolution of opposable thumbs and toes are closely linked? Options: A. They are independent adaptations, B. They are closely linked and have a common purpose, C. They are mutually exclusive and cannot coexist, D. They are not related at all Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

represented a wave of change that was already underway

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The year was 1776. In Bavaria, new ideals of rationalism, 
religious freedom, and universal human rights competed with the Catholic church’s 
heavy influence over public affairs. Across the Atlantic, a new nation staked its claim for 
independence on the basis of these ideas. But back in Bavaria, law professor Adam Weishaupt’s 
attempts to teach secular philosophy continued to be frustrated. Weishaupt decided to spread his ideas 
through a secret society that would shine a light on the 
shortcomings of the Church’s ideology. He called his secret society 
the Illuminati. Weishaupt modelled aspects of his secret 
society off a group called the Freemasons. Originally an elite stoneworkers’ 
guild in the late Middle Ages, the Freemasons had gone from passing 
down the craft of masonry to more generally promoting ideals of 
knowledge and reason. Over time, they had grown into a 
semi-secret, exclusive order that included many wealthy and 
influential individuals, with elaborate, secret initiation rituals. Weishaupt created his parallel 
society while also joining the Freemasons and recruiting from their ranks. He adopted the code name 
Spartacus for himself, after the famed leader of the 
Roman slave revolt. Early members became the Illuminati’s 
ruling council, or Areopagus. One of these members, Baron Adolph 
Knigge, was also a freemason, and became an influential recruiter. With Knigge’s help, the Illuminati 
expanded their numbers, gained influence within 
several Masonic chapters, and incorporated Masonic rituals. By 1784, there were over 600 members, including influential scholars 
and politicians. As the Illuminati gained members, the American Revolution also 
gained momentum. Thomas Jefferson would later cite 
Weishaupt as an inspiration. European monarchs and clergy were fearful 
of similar revolts on their home soil. Meanwhile, the existence of the Illuminati
had become an open secret. Both the Illuminati and the Freemasons 
drew exclusively from society’s wealthy elite, which meant they were constantly 
rubbing shoulders with members of the religious and 
political establishment. Many in the government and church 
believed that both groups were determined to undermine the 
people’s religious faith. But these groups didn’t necessarily 
oppose religion— they just believed it should be kept 
separate from governance. Still, the suspicious Bavarian government 
started keeping records of alleged members of the Illuminati. Just as Illuminati members begun to secure
important positions in local governments and universities, a 1784 decree by Duke Karl Theodor 
of Bavaria banned all secret societies. While a public ban on something ostensibly
secret might seem difficult to enforce, in this case it worked. Only nine years after its founding, the group dissolved, 
their records were seized, and Weishaupt forced into exile. The Illuminati would become more 
notorious in their afterlife than they had ever been in 
their brief existence. A decade later, in the aftermath 
of the French Revolution, conservative authors claimed the 
Illuminati had survived their banishment and orchestrated the overthrow 
of the monarchy. In the United States, preacher Jedidiah Morse promoted 
similar ideas of an Illuminati conspiracy against the government. But though the idea of a secret group 
orchestrating political upheaval is still alive and well today, there is no
evidence that the Illuminati survived, reformed, or went underground. Their brief tenure is well-documented 
in Bavarian government records, the still-active Freemasons’s records, and particularly the overlap between 
these two sources, without a whisper since. In the spirit of rationalism the 
Illuminati embraced, one must conclude they no longer exist. But the ideas that spurred Weishaupt 
to found the illuminati still spread, becoming the basis for many Western 
governments today. These ideas didn’t start or end 
with the Illuminati— instead, it was one community that 
represented a wave of change that was already underway 
when it was founded and continued long after it ended.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The Illuminati's ruling council were known as the:
Options: A. Parliamentarians, B. Areopagus, C. Spartacus, D. The chamber
Correct Option: B

Question 3: According to the transcript, what is the main advantage of nails over claws for primates? Options: A. They are sharper and more effective for hunting, B. They provide a rigid surface to press against, improving grip and sensitivity, C. They are easier to retract and extend, D. They are less likely to get damaged Correct Option: B
Question 4: How do nails improve the sensitivity of a primate's digits? Options: A. By providing a softer surface to detect changes in pressure, B. By providing an extra surface to detect changes in pressure, C. By reducing the amount of keratin produced, D. By increasing the rate at which the keratinocytes grow Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the likely reason why nails have persisted as an adaptation in primates? Options: A. They are more effective for hunting than claws, B. They provide a rigid surface to press against, improving grip and sensitivity, C. They are easier to retract and extend, D. They are less likely to get damaged Correct Option: B
Question 6: How do the evolution of nails and the evolution of opposable thumbs and toes relate to each other? Options: A. They are independent adaptations, B. They are closely linked and have a common purpose, C. They are mutually exclusive and cannot coexist, D. They are not related at all Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is an example of an unexpected way that claws are used in the animal kingdom? Options: A. Manatees use nails to grasp their food, B. Researchers think elephant toenails may sense vibrations in the ground to help them hear, C. Some primates, like the aye-ayes of Madagascar, have re-acquired claws, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 8: What is the likely reason why claws are not as effective for primates as nails? Options: A. They are sharper and more effective for hunting, B. They provide a rigid surface to press against, improving grip and sensitivity, C. Their points make grabbing difficult and potentially dangerous, D. They are easier to retract and extend Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the main advantage of nails over claws for primates in terms of their ability to create and wield complex tools? Options: A. They are sharper and more effective for hunting, B. They provide a rigid surface to press against, improving grip and sensitivity, C. Their points make grabbing difficult and potentially dangerous, D. They are easier to retract and extend Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the likely reason why the evolution of nails and the evolution of opposable thumbs and toes are closely linked? Options: A. They are independent adaptations, B. They are closely linked and have a common purpose, C. They are mutually exclusive and cannot coexist, D. They are not related at all Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The year was 1776. In Bavaria, new ideals of rationalism, 
religious freedom, and universal human rights competed with the Catholic church’s 
heavy influence over public affairs. Across the Atlantic, a new nation staked its claim for 
independence on the basis of these ideas. But back in Bavaria, law professor Adam Weishaupt’s 
attempts to teach secular philosophy continued to be frustrated. Weishaupt decided to spread his ideas 
through a secret society that would shine a light on the 
shortcomings of the Church’s ideology. He called his secret society 
the Illuminati. Weishaupt modelled aspects of his secret 
society off a group called the Freemasons. Originally an elite stoneworkers’ 
guild in the late Middle Ages, the Freemasons had gone from passing 
down the craft of masonry to more generally promoting ideals of 
knowledge and reason. Over time, they had grown into a 
semi-secret, exclusive order that included many wealthy and 
influential individuals, with elaborate, secret initiation rituals. Weishaupt created his parallel 
society while also joining the Freemasons and recruiting from their ranks. He adopted the code name 
Spartacus for himself, after the famed leader of the 
Roman slave revolt. Early members became the Illuminati’s 
ruling council, or Areopagus. One of these members, Baron Adolph 
Knigge, was also a freemason, and became an influential recruiter. With Knigge’s help, the Illuminati 
expanded their numbers, gained influence within 
several Masonic chapters, and incorporated Masonic rituals. By 1784, there were over 600 members, including influential scholars 
and politicians. As the Illuminati gained members, the American Revolution also 
gained momentum. Thomas Jefferson would later cite 
Weishaupt as an inspiration. European monarchs and clergy were fearful 
of similar revolts on their home soil. Meanwhile, the existence of the Illuminati
had become an open secret. Both the Illuminati and the Freemasons 
drew exclusively from society’s wealthy elite, which meant they were constantly 
rubbing shoulders with members of the religious and 
political establishment. Many in the government and church 
believed that both groups were determined to undermine the 
people’s religious faith. But these groups didn’t necessarily 
oppose religion— they just believed it should be kept 
separate from governance. Still, the suspicious Bavarian government 
started keeping records of alleged members of the Illuminati. Just as Illuminati members begun to secure
important positions in local governments and universities, a 1784 decree by Duke Karl Theodor 
of Bavaria banned all secret societies. While a public ban on something ostensibly
secret might seem difficult to enforce, in this case it worked. Only nine years after its founding, the group dissolved, 
their records were seized, and Weishaupt forced into exile. The Illuminati would become more 
notorious in their afterlife than they had ever been in 
their brief existence. A decade later, in the aftermath 
of the French Revolution, conservative authors claimed the 
Illuminati had survived their banishment and orchestrated the overthrow 
of the monarchy. In the United States, preacher Jedidiah Morse promoted 
similar ideas of an Illuminati conspiracy against the government. But though the idea of a secret group 
orchestrating political upheaval is still alive and well today, there is no
evidence that the Illuminati survived, reformed, or went underground. Their brief tenure is well-documented 
in Bavarian government records, the still-active Freemasons’s records, and particularly the overlap between 
these two sources, without a whisper since. In the spirit of rationalism the 
Illuminati embraced, one must conclude they no longer exist. But the ideas that spurred Weishaupt 
to found the illuminati still spread, becoming the basis for many Western 
governments today. These ideas didn’t start or end 
with the Illuminati— instead, it was one community that 
represented a wave of change that was already underway 
when it was founded and continued long after it ended.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: True or false: The illuminati were determined to undermine people’s faith
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: B
